text:
Flatbush Ave., at the S.W. corner of Kings Highway, showing the Central House, built about 1885, by John Y. McKane for Thomas Gilfeather. Now (1936) it is no longer standing.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

title: Brooklyn: Flatbush Avenue - Kings Highway

folder: Flatbush Avenue & Kings Highway, Brooklyn, NY
text:
(1)
Flatbush Ave., at the N.E. corner of King's Highway, showing "Hendrickson's corner". This building was for 66 years, kept by the Hendrickson's as a general store and post office. The upper part was uused as a meeting room, town hall and court room. J. B. Hendrickson was the original owner and thereafter his son Elias continued the business.
TThe building was remodeled in 1925.
1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
The same, a closer view.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Brooklyn: Flatbush Avenue - Kings Highway

text:
(1
Flatbush Ave., west side, between King's Highway and Flatlands Ave., showing the Peter Lott farmhouse, erected about 1857, and destroyed by fire in December 1925, now the site of the Marine Theatre. This house was occupied by Peter Lott from 1857 to 1860, by lrs Keenan in 1875
and by Mrs. Ferris J. Bergen in 1922.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
2)
The same, from another angle.
April 1923.

The same, from another angle.
AUust 1925.

folder: Flatbush Avenue & Kings Highway, Brooklyn, NY
text:
Flatbush Ave., west side, between Kings Highway and Flatlands Ave.. now (1936), approximately 78-84 Flatbush Ave.  This was known as the Peter Lott house, after Peter Lott who settled in Flatbush about 1650. His descendants, Johannes E. and Abraham Lott, purchased it from Aert Willenoss,
early in the 18th century. It has been razed.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Brooklyn: Flatbush Avenue - Kings Highway

corner of Flatbush Ave., and Kings Highway.
1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

folder: Kings Highway & Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY
text:
King's Highway, north side, between Flatbush Ave., and East 40th Street. In the background, is seen the Flatland Dutch Reform Cemetery. The old houses are landmarks of old farms, slowly disappearing in this section.

August 7, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Brooklyn: Kings Highway - Flatbush Avenue

folder: Kings Highway & Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY
text:
Kings Highway, at the N.W. corner of Flatbush Ave. It is said that the land on which this house stands, was sold by Elbert Elbertsen in 1676 to Peter Wyckoff. Iw 1797 Simon Voorhies cemwe into possession of it, and used it as a tavern. John B. Durges owned it until 1820, used it as a tavern for about 20 years. Abraham Torhune became the next owner and his estate sold it in 1843 to John Bergen who built a 2-story extension on the west side, the first floor becoming a ballroom and the second floor sleeping quarters. In 1855 John Logue became the owner. William R. Mc Neil became the owner in 1860 and in 1874 John Van Wyck bought the property and lived in it until 1882. Letween 1882 and 1895 the place became an ice cream parlor and saloon, and from 1895 to 1902 the Amersfort Hotel was kept here. In 1902 the property reverted to the heirs of John Van Wyck and was demolished in 1923.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Brooklyn: Kings Highway - Flatbush Avenue

folder: Kings Highway & Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY
text:
Kings Pighway, south side, east of Flatbush Ave., showing house and store built in 1856, occupied by Wilson Reed in 1857, and by A. C. Grane in
1873. The house was razed in May 1925.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Brooklyn: Kings Highway - Flatbush Avenue

folder: Kings Highway & Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY
text:
(1)
Kings Highway, (Kouwenhoven Lane), south side, east from Flatbush Ave., to East 40th Street, showing part of the John J. Ryder (formerly the J. C. Ryder) house on the right, and the J. 3. Hendrickson House in the extreme background. All these houses except the Hendrickson
house, were demolished in May 1925.
March 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
The same, from a point further east from Flatbush Ave., showing the Hendfickson House (in the background), and the Garretson House at
the right.
March 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(3)
The same, showing the Garretson House at the right, known once as  61 Kouwenhoven Lne. This house was occupied by the Garretson family from 1857 to 1873. At the left is seen the Hendrickson House at the N.E.
corner of Kings Highway and East 40th Street.
March 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Brooklyn: Kings Highway - Flatbush Avenue
